questions.text: Which of the following drugs used to stimulate appetite acts by antagonizing 5-HT₂ and H₁ receptors without having α₂ antagonistic action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cyproheptadine

 Detailed Explanation

 Option B: Mirtazapine → Not Correct
• Mirtazapine is a NaSSA (Noradrenergic and Specific Serotonergic Antidepressant).
• Its main actions:
o Blocks presynaptic α₂ autoreceptors → ↑ NE & 5-HT release
o Blocks 5-HT₂ and 5-HT₃ receptors → directs serotonin toward 5-HT₁A
o Blocks H₁ receptors → causes sedation and weight gain
• So it does all three: α₂, 5-HT₂, and H₁.
• Hence, it does have α₂ antagonism → not the answer.

 Option D: Cyproheptadine → Correct
• Cyproheptadine is an old first-generation antihistamine.
• It has:
o Strong H₁ antagonist activity → antihistamine, sedative, appetite stimulant
o 5-HT₂ receptor antagonist → removes serotonin’s appetite-suppressing effect
o NO significant α₂ antagonistic action
• Therefore, it stimulates appetite by blocking 5-HT₂ and H₁, but does not block α₂ receptors.

 Options A & C
A) Dronabinol — synthetic THC: works via CB1 cannabinoid receptors → increases appetite in AIDS/cachexia → no 5-HT₂/H₁ block.
C) Megestrol acetate — progestin: appetite stimulation via neuropeptide Y and other mechanisms → no direct 5-HT₂/H₁ effect.

questions.text: 45-year-old man with chronic renal failure presents with muscle weakness and ECG showing peaked T-waves and widened QRS. Labs show serum K⁺ of 7.2 mEq/L. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for immediate cardiac membrane stabilization?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Calcium gluconate

Explanations- 
Magnesium sulfate (MgSO₄)
• Indications:
o Torsades de pointes (a type of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia)
o Hypomagnesemia
o Eclampsia/seizure prevention in pregnancy
• NOT indicated for hyperkalemia
•  Wrong answer
 Calcium gluconate
• Mechanism: Stabilizes cardiac myocyte membranes by:
o Restoring the normal threshold potential
o Reducing excitability to prevent arrhythmias
• Onset: 1–3 minutes
• Duration: 30–60 minutes
• Use: First-line in any hyperkalemia with ECG changes
• Preferred over calcium chloride in peripheral IV access due to less risk of tissue necrosis
•  Correct answer

 Insulin with glucose
• Mechanism: Shifts potassium intracellularly via Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase
• Onset: 15–30 minutes
• Role: Lowers serum potassium — essential secondary step
•  But it does not stabilize cardiac membranes
•  Not the immediate action if ECG is unstable

Furosemide
• Mechanism: Loop diuretic → increases renal K⁺ excretion
• Limitation: Ineffective in chronic renal failure due to poor kidney function
•  Not useful for emergency treatment and ineffective if renal function is compromised

questions.text: Two analgesic drugs, A and B, produce maximal pain relief. Drug A achieves the effect at 5 mg, while drug B requires 50 mg for the same effect. Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Drug A is more potent but equally efficacious as drug B
Explanation:
• Potency refers to the dose required to achieve a given effect. Lower dose = higher potency.
• Efficacy refers to the maximum effect a drug can achieve.
• Since both drugs achieve the same maximum effect, their efficacy is the same.
• But Drug A is more potent because it achieves the effect at a lower dose.

questions.text: A woman is treated with a fertility drug that blocks estrogen receptors in the hypothalamus and pituitary, increasing FSH and LH levels. What drug is she most likely taking?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Clomiphene
Explanation:
What is Clomiphene?
• Clomiphene citrate is a Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator (SERM).
• Acts as an antagonist at estrogen receptors in the hypothalamus and anterior pituitary.

Mechanism of Action:
1. Normally, estrogen exerts negative feedback on the hypothalamus and pituitary, suppressing:
o GnRH (from hypothalamus)
o FSH & LH (from anterior pituitary)
2. Clomiphene blocks estrogen receptors in the hypothalamus:
o This disrupts negative feedback, making the brain "think" estrogen is low.
o Leads to increased GnRH release.
3. Increased GnRH → ↑ FSH & LH, which:
o Stimulate follicular development.
o Trigger ovulation.
Clinical Use:
• First-line drug for anovulatory infertility, especially in:
o Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)
o Luteal phase defect

Fats and bile salts increase the water content of the feces by promoting the secretion of water into the lumen of the colon.

questions.text: How does the distal nephron differ functionally from the proximal nephron?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Distal nephron has more negative intraluminal potential than the proximal tubule
Distal nephron has more negative intraluminal potential than the proximal tubule because it is poorly permeable to negatively charged ions. Therefore, sodium is reabsorbed, negatively charged ions, primarily Cl-, lag, producing a negative intraluminal potential. 
PCT secretes much more H+ than the distal nephron but acidification of urine occurs in the distal nephron. 
Aldosterone increases sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion in the distal nephron but has no effect on the PCT. 
Potassium is reabsorbed in the PCT and TAL and secreted in the distal nephron under the influence of aldosterone.

questions.text: A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman with hormone receptor–positive, HER2-negative metastatic breast cancer is started on letrozole and a targeted oral agent that inhibits phosphorylation of Rb protein by blocking cyclin D-CDK4/6 complexes. This drug enhances progression-free survival when combined with endocrine therapy. Which of the following drugs fits this profile?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
 
Palbociclib

 Explanation:
• Palbociclib is a CDK4/6 inhibitor, which prevents phosphorylation of Rb, halting the cell cycle at the G1/S checkpoint.
• It is used in HR+/HER2− advanced breast cancer, especially in combination with aromatase inhibitors like letrozole or fulvestrant.
• It improves progression-free survival significantly in this subtype.

 Incorrect Options:
• A. Olaparib is a PARP inhibitor, effective in BRCA-mutant breast cancer (HR+/HER2− or TNBC).
• B. Neratinib is a HER2 TKI, used in HER2+ cancers.
• D. Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody for HER2+ cancers, not used in HER2-negative cases.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman with acute angle-closure glaucoma presents with severe headache, nausea, and blurred vision. She is given a diuretic intra venously. During the infusion, she develops dyspnea, bibasilar crackles, and hypoxia. Which underlying condition most likely explains this adverse reaction of the given drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation-
Identify the drug
• In acute angle-closure glaucoma, the diuretic used to rapidly lower intraocular pressure (IOP) is Mannitol, an osmotic diuretic.
 Mechanism of Mannitol
• Mannitol is freely filtered in the glomerulus and not reabsorbed → pulls water into the renal tubule → promotes osmotic diuresis.
• But before it is excreted by the kidney, it expands extracellular fluid volume by pulling water out of cells into the intravascular space.
Adverse effect
• This sudden ECF expansion can:
o Increase preload.
o Raise blood volume → higher cardiac filling pressures.
o If the patient has poor cardiac reserve (like LV dysfunction), the heart can’t handle the sudden increase in intravascular volume → pulmonary venous congestion → pulmonary edema.
Why other options are less likely
Chronic liver disease:
o Hypoalbuminemia can worsen edema in general, but the immediate mechanism here is volume overload, which is directly handled by the heart. Liver disease alone wouldn’t explain acute pulmonary edema with Mannitol.
Primary hyperaldosteronism:
o Leads to sodium and water retention, but again, the acute issue is cardiac reserve. Hyperaldosteronism can cause hypertension but not the inability to handle sudden volume expansion.
Impending renal disease:
o Mannitol is contraindicated in anuria or severe renal failure because if it can’t be excreted, it stays in the ECF and worsens volume overload. However, in that case, you’d see worsening generalized edema, not specifically pulmonary edema due to failing LV function.
Uncontrolled HTN with LV dysfunction:
 Best choice — the patient’s left ventricle is already impaired → can’t manage the sudden increase in preload → pulmonary capillary hydrostatic pressure rises → fluid leaks into alveoli → dyspnea and crackles → classic pulmonary edema.

questions.text: Which one of the following is at the sub- centre level? (79)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Gram Panchayat
Explanation
The administrative system in Indian villages is primarily structured around the Panchayati Raj system, a form of local self-governance. It's a three-tiered structure, with the Gram Panchayat at the village level being the foundational unit. This system ensures that villagers have a direct say in their local governance and development. 
A. Gram Panchayat:
• This is the basic unit of local administration in rural India, often referred to as a village council or village panchayat. 
• It's responsible for the governance and administration of a village or a group of villages. 
• Members are directly elected by the villagers, ensuring democratic representation. 
• The Gram Panchayat handles local issues like sanitation, water supply, roads, and basic infrastructure. 
B. Panchayat Samiti (Block Panchayat):
• Located at the block level, this acts as an intermediate tier in the Panchayati Raj system.
• It coordinates and oversees the activities of the Gram Panchayats within its jurisdiction.
• Members are indirectly elected from the Gram Panchayats. 
C. Zila Parishad (District Panchayat):
• This is the highest tier of the Panchayati Raj system, functioning at the district level.
• It provides overall guidance and supervision to the Panchayat Samitis and Gram Panchayats.
• Like the Panchayat Samiti, its members are indirectly elected. 
The Gram Sabha is the general assembly of all adults registered to vote in a village, while the Gram Panchayat is a smaller, elected body that acts as the executive arm for village development. Essentially, the Gram Sabha is the larger body that oversees and approves the work of the Gram Panchayat.

questions.text: A 34 year old woman presented with foul smelling nasal discharge and bilateral nasal obstruction. The diagnostic examination showed a nodular mass from which a biopsy was sent for histological examination. All are true for this condition except-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ref: Read the text below
Sol:  
• Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous condition of the nose and other structures of the upper respiratory tract. Rhinoscleroma is a result of infection by the bacterium Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis also called as the Friesch bacillus.
• The occurrence of familial disease suggests that genetic control of the host response to K rhinoscleromatis may be an important factor in endemic areas.
• A positive result with culturing in MacConkey agar is diagnostic of rhinoscleroma. However, culture results are positive in only 50-60% of patients.
• Bronchoscopy has a role in the initial treatment of symptoms. 
• Treatment should also include long-term antimicrobial therapy and surgical intervention in patients with symptoms of obstruction.

questions.text: A 66 year old Chinese man presents with a two month history of neck swelling in the right posterior triangle. On further questioning he tells you that his hearing has also declined in the right ear. He also has a blocked nose. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Metastatic lymph node from a nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
Ref: Read the text below    
Sol:
• Nasopharynx cancer or nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) is the most common cancer originating in the nasopharynx, the uppermost region of the pharynx ("throat"), behind the nose where the nasal passages and auditory tubes join the remainder of the upper respiratory tract. NPC occurs in children and adults.
• NPC differs significantly from other cancers of the head and neck in its occurrence, causes, clinical behavior, and treatment. 
• It is vastly more common in certain regions of East Asia and Africa than elsewhere, with viral, dietary and genetic factors implicated in its causation. It is most common in males. It is a squamous cell carcinoma or an undifferentiated type. 
• Squamous cells are a flat type of cell found in the skin and the membranes that line some body cavities. Differentiation means how different the cancer cells are from normal cells. 
• Undifferentiated is a word used to describe cells that do not have their mature features or functions.
• Cervical lymphadenopathy (disease or swelling of the lymph nodes in the neck) is the initial presentation in many patients, and the diagnosis of NPC is often made by lymph node biopsy. Symptoms related to the primary tumor include trismus, pain, otitis media, nasal regurgitation due to paresis (loss of or impaired movement) of the soft palate, hearing loss and cranial nerve palsies (paralysis). 
• Larger growths may produce nasal obstruction or bleeding and a "nasal twang". Metastatic spread may result in bone pain or organ dysfunction. Rarely, a paraneoplastic syndrome of osteoarthropathy (diseases of joints and bones) may occur with widespread disease.

questions.text: A teenaged girl was seen for a school physical examination. Screening audiometry performed in the office revealed a 30-dB (mild) elevation of hearing thresholds at 4,000 Hz. A confirmatory audiogram taken by an audiologist showed a sensorineural loss (Fig). In response to questioning, the girl reported spending several hours a day listening to music through head-phones. The previous night, she had spent several hours at a rock concert without wearing hearing protection. Afterward, she noticed that her ears were ringing and “felt like there was cotton in them.” Several days later, her hearing had returned to normal. In NIHL, which part of the cochlea is principally damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Outer hair cells (OHCs)
Ref: Read the text below.
Sol:-
• The audiogram in NIHL shows a typical notch, at 4 kHz, both for air and bone conduction. It is usually symmetrical on both sides. 
• At this stage, patient complains of high-pitched tinnitus and difficulty in hearing in noisy surroundings but no difficulty in day-to-day hearing. 
• As the duration of noise exposure increases, the notch deepens and also widens to involve lower and higher frequencies.
• Hearing impairment becomes clinically apparent to the patient when the frequencies of 500, 1000 and 2000 Hz (the speech frequencies) are also affected.NIHL causes damage to hair cells, starting in the basal turn of cochlea. 
• Outer hair cells are affected before the inner hair cells.
• Noise-induced hearing loss is preventable

questions.text: A direct or indirect intervention taken by the government to bring change in the existing behaviour:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Regulatory approach
Explanation 
Health education approaches aim to improve individual and community health by providing knowledge, skills, and resources to make informed health decisions and adopt healthy behaviours.
Primary healthcare approach, the focus is on empowering individuals, families, and communities to actively participate in their own health and well-being.
Service approach in health focuses on meeting individual and community needs by providing accessible, equitable, and high-quality healthcare services. This approach emphasizes patient-centred care, where healthcare providers prioritize understanding and responding to individual preferences, needs, and values. It also involves community involvement and intersectoral collaboration to address the broader determinants of health.
Regulatory approach in health education involves using government laws and enforcement to promote health behaviours and protect public health.

questions.text: A 32 year old male was brought with fracture shaft humerus. Explanation 
Immediate open reduction and internal fixation of the fracture with radial nerve exploration

Short Explanation:
The patient initially had no radial nerve palsy, but developed wrist drop after plaster application.
This indicates a secondary (iatrogenic or positional) nerve injury, likely due to:
 • Entrapment of radial nerve in fracture site
 • Compression due to tight cast or poor positioning
In such a scenario, urgent surgical exploration is required to relieve the nerve and fix the fracture, as delaying may cause permanent nerve damage.
Hence, ORIF with radial nerve exploration is the correct choice.

questions.text: A child presented with growth failure and polyurea. MRI image is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

• Craniopharyngioma are generally benign typically arise in the sellar or suprasellar region of the brain, near the pituitary gland and hypothalamus.
• It is a partly cystic embryonic malformation.
• Craniopharyngiomas can compress normal pituitary tissue and result in pituitary deficiencies, particularly of the anterior pituitary hormones
• 85% of adult patients will have growth hormone (GH) deficiency presenting as non-specific symptoms like weight gain, central obesity, and fatigue. Approximately 25 % of patients will have adrenocortical hormone (ACTH) deficiency and TSH deficiency. Vasopressin deficiency (diabetes insipidus) is reported in approximately 20% of patients.
• It can also compress the optic chiasm and/or optic nerves and cause different degrees and types of visual disturbances, from blurry vision to blindness.
• Treatment typically involves surgery to remove the tumor, and sometimes radiation therapy is used to treat any remaining tumor cells. The most common surgical approaches are endoscopic endonasal transsphenoidal (EET) or transcranial

questions.text: Which of the following flowmeter arrangements would be the most likely to lead to a hypoxic gas mixture?

questions.text: A 25 year old soccer player complained of injury to right knee 6 months ago. Now he says that there is a feeling of sudden giving away of knee joint with knee in 90 degree flexion which completely disappears when the knee is taken into complete extension. Which of the following ligament needs to be checked ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Explanation : 
The ACL (anterior cruciate ligament) has two bundles — anteromedial (AM) and posterolateral (PL).
 • The AM bundle is tight in flexion, while
 • The PL bundle is tight in extension.
In this case, the patient experiences instability (giving way) at 90° flexion, which resolves in extension.
This suggests dysfunction of the anteromedial bundle, since it is responsible for stabilization in flexion.
Hence, the anteromedial bundle of ACL should be checked.

questions.text: Which of the following would cause an abrupt decrease in the end-tidal CO2 (ETCO2) during general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

• An abrupt decrease in the ETCO2 is often linked with a life-threatening predicament and is almost always associated with either a ventilation or perfusion issue.
• Examples include sudden severe hypotension, endotracheal tube migration, massive pulmonary embolism, and cardiac arrest.
• When an abrupt decrease in ETCO2 is noted, it should be quickly verified and addressed.
• During cardiopulmonary resuscitation, adequacy of circulation can be monitored via return of the ETCO2.

questions.text: Injuries caused by air born debris and bomb fragments is classified under which category?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


• Primary blast—unique to high-order explosives; results from the impact of the over-pressurization wave with body surfaces.

• Secondary blast—results from flying debris and bomb fragments.

• Tertiary blast—results from individuals being thrown by the blast wind.

• Quaternary blast—all explosion-related injuries, illnesses, or diseases not due to primary, secondary, or tertiary mechanisms—includes exacerbation or complications of existing conditions.
• Quinary injury- hyperinflammatory behavior by exposure to environmental contaminants, including chemicals, radiation, viruses, and bacteria

The most common primary blast injuries include:
• Ear—tympanic membrane (eardrum) rupture
• Blast lung—pulmonary barotraumas
• Abdomen—hemorrhage and hollow organ perforation

This child, who has never spoken voluntarily and who shows no interest in or connection to his parents, other adults, or other children despite normal hearing, probably has ASD. Any change in his environment, such as being dressed, leads to intense discomfort, struggling, and screaming.

questions.text: Following an emergency caesarean section under general anaesthesia, the patient presents with respiratory distress and tachycardia in recovery. Auscultation reveals coarse crepitations in right lower lobe. Her condition is most likely due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

• Aspiration is the most common cause of maternal anaesthesia-related mortality.
• The risk of aspiration pneumonitis can be decreased by reducing the volume and acidity of the gastric contents.
• The gastric emptying time is prolonged in labour.
• Extubation should be performed with the patient fully awake.
• Patients who aspirate may develop clinical signs and symptoms several hours after the incident.
• Aspiration is potentially a risk in all patients with reduced consciousness.
• The treatment is mainly supportive.
• It includes oxygen therapy and bronchodilators.
• It may often be necessary to remove large particulate matter using bronchoscopy.
• Use of prophylactic antibiotics and steroids is not advised
• CPAP or intermittent positive pressure ventilation with PEEP may be necessary in severe cases.

questions.text: All of the following are properties of CTEV Shoes except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Explanation:
CTEV (Clubfoot) shoes are designed to maintain correction and prevent recurrence. Their key features include:
 No heel – promotes dorsiflexion
 Straight inner border – prevents forefoot adduction
 Outer shoe raise – encourages eversion of the foot
Inner shoe raise would promote inversion, which is undesirable in clubfoot correction.
Hence, inner shoe raise is not a feature of CTEV shoes.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is noted to have worsening visual acuity on serial eye exams. Recent MRI of his brain and orbits reveals an optic chiasm mass, most consistent with an optic pathway glioma. Upon further examination, the physician notes axillary freckling and numerous “spots” on the patient’s skin. This patient most likely has a which of the following genetic disorders?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Children with neurofibromatosis type-1 (NF-1) have about a 15% to 20% risk of developing low-grade optic gliomas. They also have a variety of other abnormalities such as axillary freckling and café-au-lait spots. 
Li Fraumeni syndrome is associated with p53 mutations and high-grade tumors, like high-grade gliomas and sarcomas. 
The characteristic brain tumor in tuberous sclerosis is a subependymal giant cell astrocytoma (SEGA). 
Patients with cystic fibrosis are not at increased risk of CNS tumors.

questions.text: On biopsy from Liver secondary it was found to be positive for CK 20 positive and CK 7 negative. What is the most probable site for primary.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Colon cancer and Merkel cell cancer- CK 20 + and CK7 -ve

questions.text: A 27 year old man presents with a left testicular tumour and a 10 cm retroperitoneal node mass with high AFP. What is the best treatment for him?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Stage IIC and III non seminoma of testis is treated by High inguinal orchidectomy and Chemotherapy.

questions.text: The wife of a 62-year-old man tells the doctor that for the past year, her husband has punched and kicked her repeatedly during the night. When she wakes him during these episodes, her husband relates that he has been having a dream in which he is trying to escape from or fighting with a frightening attacker. Over the next few years, this man is at increased risk to develop
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Lewy Body Dementia 
Dreaming typically occurs during REM sleep. Because typically there is muscle atonia during REM sleep, this man who is moving while dreaming is showing signs of REM sleep behavior disorder. This disorder is associated with an increased risk for Parkinson’s disease and Lewy body dementia.

questions.text: In tumour lysis syndrome, which drug is used to reduce renal damage due to hyperuricosuria
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
• Recombinant urate oxidase; catalyzes the oxidation of uric acid into allantoin, a soluble metabolite of uric acid

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute indication for surgical treatment of a renal injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Expanding perirenal hematoma
 Absolute Indications of Exploration
1. Evidence of Persistent renal bleeding
2. Expanding perirenal hematoma
3. Pulsatile perirenal hematoma
Relative Indications
– Urinary extravasation
– Non-Viable tissue >20%
– Delayed diagnosis of arterial injury
– Segmental arterial injury
– Incomplete staging

questions.text: 9-year-old boy with normal intelligence does not obey his parents, is angry, irritable and vindictive in nature. He has a history of fighting with other children and catching and torturing birds, squirrels, and rabbits. When asked why he engages in this behavior, he says, “It’s just fun.” Developmental history and medical examination are unremarkable. The best explanation of this child’s behavior is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Conduct Disorder 
This child is showing evidence of conduct disorder(violation of rights of others). Children with this disorder have little or no concern for others or for animals (e.g., this child finds torturing animals “fun”)

questions.text: A patient after receiving 2 units of blood developed breathlessness. On examination pedal edema was observed, his PR is 108/min and his BP was 156/100 mmHg. Xray chest is normal. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
• Transfusion associated cardiac overload: Transfusion associated circulatory overload includes any four of the following occurring within 6 h of transfusion - acute respiratory distress, tachycardia, increased blood pressure (BP), acute or worsening pulmonary edema and evidence of a positive fluid balance.

• TRALI- Transfusion associated lung injury- Presents with dyspnoea, edema and ARDS like features in X-ray chest.

choices.text: Alpha blockers (Phenoxybenzamine) is the first drug to be given for preparation for surgery
Propranolol can be added later on if tachycardia persists
MRI may give Swiss cheese or light bulb sign
Halothane is considered the anaesthetic drug of choice

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Drugs used in pheochromocytoma are propofol, etomidate, fentanyl, alfentanil, remifentanil, and benzodiazepines for induction, and vecuronium or rocuronium for neuromuscular blockade. Volatile anaesthetics like isoflurane and sevoflurane are also considered safe. However, ketamine and drugs with direct or indirect alpha and beta-agonist effects (like ephedrine or epinephrine) should be avoided.
Problems with Halothane in Pheochromocytoma:-
• Myocardial Sensitization leading to arrhythmias.
• Hemodynamic Instability: Dramatic swings in blood pressure.
• Liver Dysfunction:

choices.text: Leave the child and search for an AED
Deliver rescue breaths as most cardiac arrest occur due to breathing problems
Begin back blows and chest thrusts
Deliver 30 chest compressions followed by 2 breaths for 2 mins and then leave the child to call for help

questions.text: After finding an unresponsive child while walking through the park, and confirming the child isn't breathing what would be your next course of action?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Identify the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

choices.text: Rapid peristalsis in the small intestine
Bacterial overgrowth in a stagnant section of the small intestine

questions.text: Blind Loop Syndrome is characterized by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Bacterial overgrowth in a stagnant section of the small intestine. The stagnation of food and digestive juices in a bypassed or narrowed section of the small intestine leads to bacterial overgrowth

questions.text: Most common posterior mediastinal tumour?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: rTMS (repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation) is used in psychiatry in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

All of the above
rTMS is used in 
Depression 
OCD 
PTSD 
Migraine 
Bradykinesia in PD 
Refractory hallucinations in schizophrenia

questions.text: A 25-year-old primipara has an accidental Dural tap (ADT) with a 16-G Tuohy needle while the anaesthetist was attempting labour epidural analgesia. A day after the ADT, the patient is complaining of severe positional frontal and occipital headache. Which of the following is not appropriate as first line of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

There is no evidence for prophylactic bed rest in post-dural puncture headache. All the other mentioned treatments have some benefit, with the blood patch having the best results.
Management of PDPH

Conservative management approaches include:
•  Bed rest
• Encouraging intake of oral fl uids and/or intravenous hydration
• Reassurance.

Pharmacological approaches include:
• Caffeine — either intravenous (e.g. 500 mg caff eine in 1 L saline) or orally
• Regular analgesia: paracetamol, diclofenac etc.
• 5HT agonists (e.g.sumatriptan)

Interventional approaches include:

• epidural blood patch, which involves injecting approximately 20 mL of the patient’s own fresh blood (taken in a strict sterile fashion) into the epidural space near the site of the suspected puncture.
• It is successful in most cases, and the onset of relief from headache may be immediate (but occasionally takes up to 24 h).
• In patients in whom a blood patch is not successful, or where relief is temporary, it may be repeated, although the likelihood of improvement is reduced.

questions.text: A young boy presents with rectal bleed and found to have a rectal polyp. After colonoscopic snaring of polyp, the biopsy showed present of gland cells and mucin. What is the likely polyp type in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
• Juvenile rectal polyps are benign, hamartomatous growths commonly found in the rectum of children and adolescents. They are characterized by cystic dilation of glandular structures within the lamina propria. 
• While usually benign, they can cause rectal bleeding, abdominal pain, or prolapse. They are typically pedunculated (attached by a stalk), reddish-brown, and may have a granular surface. 
• Polypectomy is the usual treatment

choices.text: Injury in left dome of diaphragm

questions.text: A lady presented with stab injury in the left upper abdomen. She was hemodynamically stable and CECT showed a laceration in spleen. Laparoscopy was planned. But as soon as the pneumoperitoneum was created her PaO2 dropped suddenly. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

In penetrating injury of left abdomen causing splenic tear, left diaphragmatic injury is likely which will lead to pneumothorax while crating pneumoperitoneum in abdomen.

questions.text: Isolated hyperthermic limb perfusion is done for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

In-transit melanoma. Melphalan is typically the drug of choice for regional chemotherapy. It is an alkylating agent.

questions.text: Components of APACHE-2 scoring include all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
APACHE II Scoring System
• Temperature (Degrees C)
• Mean Arterial Pressure (mmHg)
• Heart Rate
• Respiratory Rate
• A-aPO2(FiO2>50%) or PaO2(FiO2<50%)
• Arterial pH or HCO3
• Serum Na+ (mEq/L)
• Serum K+ (mEq/L)
• Serum Creatinine (ARF means Acute Renal Failure)
• Hematocrit
• WBC Count (109/L)
• Glasgow Coma Score
• Age
• ARF/ Severe organ failure/ Immunocompromised (Yes/No)

questions.text: Which of the following is the best indicator of adequacy of ventilation in neonates?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

improved HR

questions.text: Hounsfield units is used in CT density scale to measure the attenuation value of different materials compared to water. The value of fat in HU would be around:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

-100
Hounsfield Units (HU) are a standardized scale used in CT imaging to measure the density (attenuation) of tissues relative to water, which is assigned a value of 0 HU. Fat typically has a negative HU value because it attenuates less X-ray than water. The attenuation value of fat generally ranges from about -50 to -150 HU, with -100 HU being a commonly referenced average. This negative value reflects fat’s lower density compared to water and soft tissues, making it distinguishable on CT scans.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida at 38 weeks gestation presents with a fetal heart rate of 180 bpm and maternal fever. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Chorioamnionitis
Explanation: Fetal tachycardia (180 bpm) with maternal fever at term suggests chorioamnionitis, an intra-amniotic infection requiring antibiotics and delivery. Fetal distress is a broad term, anemia causes sinusoidal patterns, and dehydration is less likely without other signs.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions will you not see eggshell calcification of lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bronchogenic carcinoma
Eggshell calcification of lymph nodes refers to a thin, rim-like calcification seen around the periphery of lymph nodes. This pattern is classically associated with certain chronic granulomatous or occupational lung diseases, but it is not typically seen in bronchogenic carcinoma. Bronchogenic carcinoma may cause lymph node enlargement or irregular calcifications if treated, but eggshell calcification is not a feature of this malignancy.

choices.text: Among infants who are depressed at birth, direct suctioning of the trachea is not associated with a reduced incidence of meconium aspiration syndrome (MAS).
Among infants who are depressed at birth, direct suctioning of the trachea is not associated with reduced mortality.
Meconium management strategies should be altered based on the consistency of the meconium (i.e., “thin” versus “thick”).
There is no benefit in routine endotracheal intubation with direct suctioning of the trachea in vigorous newborns.
There is no benefit to suctioning the oropharynx at the perineum, prior to the delivery of the shoulders.

questions.text: The NRP recommendations about suctioning of infants delivered with meconium-stained amniotic fluid (MSAF) has changed over the years as new evidence has emerged. Based upon the current published evidence, and most recent NRP guidelines, which of the following statements is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Meconium management strategies should be altered based on the consistency of the meconium (i.e., “thin” versus “thick”).
The management of infants who are delivered through meconium-stained amniotic fluid (MSAF) has changed considerably over the years as new evidence has emerged. For example. historically, all infants had their oropharynx suctioned prior to delivery of the shoulders, and once delivered, all infants were intubated to directly suction the trachea, independent of their clinical condition. However, following publication of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) demonstrating no benefit to these treatment strategies, these practices have been slowly abandoned.  Direct endotracheal suctioning has not been associated with either a reduced incidence of MAS or a reduction in mortality.

questions.text: A 32-year-old G2P1 at 39 weeks gestation presents in active labour. Her cervix is 6 cm dilated, and the fetal heart rate shows late decelerations. What is the most likely cause of the decelerations?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Uteroplacental insufficiency
Explanation: Late decelerations on fetal heart rate monitoring are characterized by a gradual decrease in heart rate during a contraction, with recovery after the contraction ends. They result from uteroplacental insufficiency, where reduced placental blood flow during contractions causes fetal hypoxia. Cord compression causes variable decelerations (sudden onset), fetal head compression causes early decelerations (mirroring contractions), and fetal anemia may cause sinusoidal patterns, not late decelerations.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old boy is seen for a health supervision visit. His parents report that he sat at 12 months of age and crawled 15 months of age. The boy started to exhibit seizures at 10 months of age, which have become more frequent. He recently stopped crawling. Physical examination findings are significant for hypotonia and an exaggerated startle response. A dilated funduscopic examination shows a cherry-red spot on the retina.
Of the following the diagnosis MOST consistent with the boy’s clinical features is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
The boy in the vignette, with gross motor delay and regression, seizures, hypotonia, exaggerated startle response, and cherry-red spot on his retina, has Tay-Sachs disease (TSD). Tay-Sachs disease is part of a continuum of disorders caused by deficiency of the enzyme β-hexosaminidase A (HEXA), which is needed to break down GM2 ganglioside. In the absence of this enzyme, GM2 ganglioside is aggregated in the lysosomes of brain and nerve cells, leading to the clinical features of the disease. The spectrum of disorders caused by HEXA deficiency includes acute infantile, subacute juvenile, and late-onset TSD. Clinical features expressed depend on the amount of enzyme present. The child in the vignette is seen with acute infantile TSD.
Clinical features of acute infantile TSD include:
• Early-onset hypotonia and gross motor delay
• Sustained ankle clonus, hyperreflexia, increased or exaggerated startle response
• Regression of motor skills at 6 to 9 months
• Decreased attention
• Cherry-red spot of the fovea centralis of the macula of the retina
• Seizure onset at around 1 year of age
• No hepatomegaly or splenomegaly
• Brain magnetic resonance imaging: ventricular enlargement starting at 18 months of age

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with a 2 cm ovarian cyst detected on ultrasound. She is asymptomatic. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Observation with follow-up ultrasound
Explanation: A 2 cm asymptomatic ovarian cyst is likely a functional cyst (e.g., follicular or corpus luteum), which typically resolves spontaneously. Follow-up ultrasound in 6-8 weeks confirms resolution. Surgery is unnecessary unless the cyst persists or grows. Oral contraceptives or GnRH agonists are not required for asymptomatic simple cysts.

questions.text: Which one of the following clinical condition requires treatment with the following device?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

urinary retention
This is ring pessary. It is used for prolapse in patients where surgery is not indicated or possible. It may cause urinary retention which will require removal and insertion of smaller sized pessary.

questions.text: Technetium-99m labelled heat-denatured RBC’s are used to diagnose pathology in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Spleen
Technetium-99m labelled heat-denatured red blood cells (RBCs) are specifically used for spleen imaging. When RBCs are heat-denatured, they become damaged and are selectively sequestered and phagocytosed by the reticuloendothelial system, primarily in the spleen. This property allows for highly sensitive and specific imaging of splenic tissue, including detecting accessory spleens, splenic infarcts, or splenic trauma. It is particularly useful in differentiating splenic tissue from other masses or lesions.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman undergoes a Pap smear, which shows high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL). Colposcopy confirms CIN III involving all 4 quadrants of cervical transformation zone. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP)
Explanation: CIN III (cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade III) is a high-grade lesion with a significant risk of progression to cervical cancer. LEEP is the preferred treatment here, as it removes the affected cervical tissue while preserving fertility. Repeat Pap smear delays treatment, cryotherapy is less precise here, and hysterectomy is overly aggressive unless invasive cancer is confirmed.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P1 at 35 weeks gestation presents with a blood pressure of 150/95 mmHg and no proteinuria. Her previous ANC visits were uneventful. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Gestational hypertension
Explanation: Blood pressure of 150/95 mmHg at 35 weeks without proteinuria indicates gestational hypertension, which occurs after 20 weeks without preeclampsia features. Preeclampsia requires proteinuria or severe features, chronic hypertension predates pregnancy, and eclampsia involves seizures.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with primary infertility for 2 years. Hysterosalpingography (HSG) shows bilateral tubal blockage at cornual region. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hysterolaparoscopy
Whenever HSG is abnormal, we must do HL scopy to confirm the findings of HSG and repair if possible.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a 6-week history of amenorrhea and a positive pregnancy test. Ultrasound shows an empty gestational sac of 2cm. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Repeat ultrasound in 1 week
Explanation: An empty gestational sac of 20mm at 6 weeks with a positive pregnancy test may indicate an anembryonic pregnancy or an early viable pregnancy. Repeating the ultrasound in 1 week confirms the diagnosis (e.g., no embryo growth suggests miscarriage). Expectant management, methotrexate, or surgery are premature without confirmation.

questions.text:
A pregnant woman initially presents for prenatal care at 28 weeks’ gestation. Upon review of her history, she reports systemic hypertension in her past medical history and medication use of captopril throughout her pregnancy. You counsel her on the potential teratogenic effects of captopril.
Of the following, the most likely fetal risk associated with maternal captopril is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

Renal tubular dysgenesis
Captopril and other angiotension converting enzyme inhibitors pose the greatest risk to the fetus if exposure occurs in 2nd or 3rd trimester. Teratogenic effects include the following:
•Renal tubular dysgenesis
•Hypoplasia of the skull
•Fetal compression syndrome with limb deformities
•Pulmonary hypoplasia in the setting of oligohydramnios

questions.text: A 34-year-old G2P1 at 37 weeks gestation presents with ruptured membranes and no uterine contractions. She is Group B Streptococcus (GBS) positive. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Oxytocin induction with penicillin prophylaxis
Explanation: A GBS-positive woman at 37 weeks with preterm premature rupture of membranes (PROM) requires immediate labour induction with oxytocin to reduce infection risk. Penicillin prophylaxis is essential to prevent neonatal GBS sepsis. Expectant management increases maternal and fetal infection risk at term. Cesarean section is not indicated unless fetal distress occurs. Oral antibiotics and discharge are inadequate.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding. Ultrasound shows a 6 cm submucosal fibroid. She desires future fertility. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Myomectomy
Explanation: A 6 cm submucosal fibroid causing heavy bleeding in a woman desiring fertility is best treated with myomectomy, which removes the fibroid while preserving the uterus. Hysterectomy eliminates fertility, uterine artery embolization may impair fertility, and GnRH agonists offer temporary relief but do not address the fibroid long-term.

questions.text: A 38-year-old G4P3 at 40 weeks gestation is in labour. The fetal heart rate shows variable decelerations. Amnioinfusion is performed. What is the most likely cause of the decelerations?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cord compression
Explanation: Variable decelerations (sudden, variable onset) are caused by umbilical cord compression, often relieved by amnioinfusion to cushion the cord. Uteroplacental insufficiency causes late decelerations, fetal hypoxia is a general term, and maternal hypotension is less likely without clinical signs.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with irregular vaginal bleeding for 6 months. She has a history of obesity and anovulatory cycles. Endometrial biopsy reveals complex hyperplasia without atypia. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Progestin therapy
Explanation: Complex endometrial hyperplasia without atypia in an obese woman with anovulatory cycles (likely due to PCOS) is caused by unopposed estrogen exposure. Progestin therapy (e.g., medroxyprogesterone acetate or levonorgestrel IUD) reverses hyperplasia by counteracting oestrogen’s proliferative effects. Hysterectomy is reserved for atypical hyperplasia or malignancy due to cancer risk.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G3P2 at 28 weeks gestation presents with vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain. Ultrasound shows a normally implanted placenta. The cervix is closed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Placental abruption
Explanation: Vaginal bleeding with abdominal pain and a closed cervix at 28 weeks, with a normally implanted placenta, suggests placental abruption (premature placental separation). This condition often presents with painful bleeding and can cause fetal distress. Placenta previa causes painless bleeding, vasa previa involves fetal vessels (rare and ultrasound-detected), and cervical polyps cause irregular, painless bleeding.

questions.text:
A male infant is born at 37 2/7 weeks’ gestation to a woman with a history of a seizure disorder. Her seizures have been very difficult to manage, so she remained on antiepileptic medication during this pregnancy. Soon after birth, the pediatrician examines the infant and identifies a small lumbosacral myelomeningocele, hypospadias, and postaxial polydactyly on both hands.
Which medication is most likely to account for these clinical findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

Valproate
Overall, the risk of major congenital malformations in pregnant women taking antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) is 4% to 6%, compared to 2% to 3% in the overall population. The risk of malformations is influenced by the gestational timing, the type of medication, and the number of medications required for treatment.
The highest risk for malformations is associated with the use of multiple AEDs in the first trimester, with at least one of the medications being Valproate. Valproate has a dose-dependent risk of major malformations, with neural tube defects occurring in 1% to 2% of exposed infants. Other associated major malformations include cleft palate, hypospadias, craniosynostosis, and polydactyly. The overall prevalence of major birth defects in exposed infants is 9%.

choices.text: Closing the subcutaneous tissue during abdominal hysterectomy
Closing the blind space during abdominal myomectomy

questions.text: Which one of the following is not an indication of using the following suture material?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
cervical cerclage
Cervical cerclage should be done with non-absorbable suture since it does not cause inflammation and fibrosis. It has to be removed at term. Catgut is an absorbable suture.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of amenorrhea. Serum prolactin is elevated, and MRI shows a 1 cm pituitary adenoma. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bromocriptine
Explanation: A 1 cm pituitary prolactinoma causing amenorrhea and hyperprolactinemia is treated with bromocriptine, a dopamine agonist that shrinks the tumour and normalizes prolactin levels. Surgery is reserved for resistant cases, radiation is rarely used, and observation is inadequate for symptomatic cases.

questions.text: A 29-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks gestation is diagnosed with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). Her fasting blood sugar is 110 mg/dL, and postprandial sugar is 160 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Dietary modification

 Explanation: Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) with fasting blood sugar of 110 mg/dL and postprandial sugar of 160 mg/dL requires initial management with dietary modification and lifestyle changes (e.g., low-glycaemic diet, regular exercise). If glycaemic control is not achieved (target fasting less than equal to 95 mg/dL, 2-hour postprandial 1 is less than equal to 120 mg/dL), medications are given.

choices.text: Expectant management with antibiotics and steroids

questions.text: A 32-year-old G3P2 at 26 weeks gestation presents with preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM). What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Expectant management with antibiotics and steroids
Explanation: PPROM at 26 weeks is managed expectantly to prolong pregnancy, with antibiotics (e.g., erythromycin) to reduce infection risk and corticosteroids (e.g., betamethasone) to enhance fetal lung maturity. Immediate delivery risks prematurity, tocolysis alone is insufficient, and antibiotics without steroids miss lung maturation benefits.

questions.text: Which of the following is the dose of ETT epinephrine in neonates?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

1ml/kg; 1:10,000

Epinephrine can be administered intravenously (IV) or endotracheally; IV administration is preferred because it is more efficacious. However, the endotracheal route can be used while IV access is being obtained:
●IV administration – IV epinephrine is given at a dose of 0.01 to 0.03 mg/kg (0.1 to 0.3 mL/kg of a 0.1 mg/mL solution [may be labeled 1:10,000]).
●Via ETT – If epinephrine is given through an ETT, the dose is 0.05 to 0.1 mg/kg (0.5 to 1 mL/kg of a 0.1 mg/mL solution [may be labeled 1:10,000])

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida at 34 weeks gestation presents with itching all over her body, worse at night. Liver function tests show elevated bile acids. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy
Explanation: Generalized itching (worse at night) and elevated bile acids at 34 weeks suggest intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP). ICP increases fetal risks like stillbirth, requiring ursodeoxycholic acid and early delivery (37-38 weeks). Acute fatty liver presents with liver failure, preeclampsia involves hypertension/proteinuria, and viral hepatitis is less pregnancy-specific.

choices.text: Intravenous corticosteroids followed by IV trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole
Intravenous corticosteroids followed by IV levofloxacin

questions.text: A 17-year-old male with AIDS presents with worsening exertional dyspnea, fever, and a nonproductive cough. His temperature is 102 F, heart rate 120 beats/min, and respiratory rate 19. A physical exam reveals mild crackles and rhonchi bilaterally. A chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates. He has no known drug allergies. What is the best initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Intravenous corticosteroids followed by IV trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole
Corticosteroids decrease mortality in patients with severe Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (PCP).
Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole is the drug of choice, but pentamidine is used for those with sulfa allergy. Levofloxacin does not cover PCP. However, if there are infiltrates, it can be added for possible bacterial pneumonia. Adjunctive corticosteroids can decrease the inflammatory response associated with PCP. Also, they can reduce the decline of oxygenation and reduce the incidence of respiratory failure.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida at 36 weeks gestation presents with complaints of headache, blurred vision, and epigastric pain for 2 days. Her BP is 160/100 mmHg, and urine dipstick shows 2+ proteinuria. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Magnesium sulphate
Explanation: The patient presents with severe preeclampsia, characterized by a blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg, proteinuria (2+), and symptoms like headache, blurred vision, and epigastric pain, indicating end-organ involvement. Magnesium sulphate is the first-line therapy to prevent seizures (eclampsia) in severe preeclampsia. It is administered as a loading dose (4-6 g IV) followed by a maintenance dose (1-2 g/hour). Oral labetalol is used for blood pressure control but does not address seizure risk. Emergency cesarean section or induction of labour may be considered after stabilization, but magnesium sulphate is the priority to prevent convulsions.

questions.text: Which of the following is autosomal recessive?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Cystic fibrosis
CF is caused by pathogenic variants in CFTR, a large (250 kilobase) gene on the long arm (q) of chromosome 7

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents with a history of recurrent pregnancy loss. Her workup reveals a uterine septum. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hysteroscopic resection
Explanation: A uterine septum is a congenital anomaly linked to recurrent pregnancy loss due to impaired implantation. Hysteroscopic resection corrects the defect, improving pregnancy outcomes. IVF does not address the septum, cerclage is for cervical incompetence, and no intervention risks further losses.

choices.text: Pelvic floor muscle exercises and mid urethral tape

questions.text: A 33-year-old G2P2 presents with urinary incontinence when coughing or sneezing. Pelvic exam shows no prolapse. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pelvic floor muscle exercises and mid urethral tape
Explanation: Stress urinary incontinence (SUI) without prolapse is initially managed with pelvic floor muscle exercises (Kegel exercises) to strengthen the pelvic floor. Bladder training is for urge incontinence, oxybutynin treats overactive bladder. Mid urethral tape will be used as a surgical treatment to provide support to the bladder-neck.

questions.text: Given below is the CT abdomen of a patient who presented with diarrhea. He is most likely to be suffering from:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pseudomembranous colitis
Pseudomembranous colitis is an inflammatory condition of the colon caused primarily by Clostridioides difficile infection, often following antibiotic use. On CT abdomen, typical findings include diffuse thickening of the colonic wall with the characteristic “accordion sign” (caused by trapped contrast between thickened haustral folds) and pericolonic fat stranding. The presentation with diarrhea and these imaging findings strongly supports pseudomembranous colitis.

questions.text: A woman with bipolar disorder seeks obstetric care during her second trimester. When obtaining her history, the obstetrician learns that she has been taking lithium daily. Prenatal counseling of this woman should include a discussion that maternal lithium use can lead to what potential teratogenic effect on a fetus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ebstein’s anomaly
Antenatal lithium exposure is generally thought to be associated with teratogenic effects that primarily involve the heart. Cardiac malformations that have been observed include Ebstein anomaly (abnormalities of the tricuspid valve and right ventricle), right ventricular outflow tract obstruction defects, coarctation of the aorta, and mitral atresia

questions.text: A 34-year-old G2P1 at 37 weeks gestation presents with reduced fetal movements. Non-stress test is non-reactive, and biophysical profile score is 4/10. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Immediate cesarean section
Explanation: A non-reactive non-stress test and a biophysical profile score of 4/10 at 37 weeks indicate fetal compromise, requiring immediate cesarean delivery to prevent stillbirth or hypoxia. Repeating tests delays care, induction is riskier with poor fetal status, and steroids are unnecessary at term.

choices.text: Discontinuation of the long-acting beta2 agonist

questions.text: A 12-year-old with perennial aeroallergies has severe persistent asthma which is not well controlled with step 5 therapy with high dose inhaled corticosteroids and long-acting beta agonist. Which of the following options should be considered?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Omalizumab should be considered in patients with documented perennial aeroallergen sensitivity and moderate to severe asthma which is not well controlled. Omalizumab is an anti IgE monoclonal antibody.
Omalizumab is now FDA approved for patients ages 6 years and older.
Safety and efficacy in children less than 6 years of age have not been established.

questions.text: A cystic lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification is seen on the MRI. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Craniopharyngioma
Craniopharyngioma is the most likely diagnosis for a cystic lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification seen on MRI. This benign tumor arises from remnants of Rathke’s pouch and typically occurs in the suprasellar area. It often presents as a mixed cystic and solid mass with characteristic calcifications visible on imaging. These calcifications are a hallmark feature, helping to differentiate craniopharyngioma from other lesions. The cystic component often contains a thick, oily fluid, contributing to its appearance on MRI.

questions.text: A 27 years old Primigravida has twin gestation with USG suggestive of the following picture. When is the ideal time of delivery of these twins?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

38 weeks
This is a case of dichorionic diamniotic twins with a thick septum in between the two babies. DCDA twins must be delivered by 38 weeks.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida at 30 weeks gestation presents with fever and dysuria. Urine culture grows Escherichia coli. Which of the following will be used in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Nitrofurantoin
Explanation: UTI in pregnancy (fever, dysuria, flank pain, E. coli) is safely treated with nitrofurantoin, a pregnancy category B drug effective for UTIs in T2 and T3 of pregnancy. Ciprofloxacin and doxycycline are contraindicated (category D), and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is avoided due to teratogenic risks.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with a vulvar ulcer and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. Dark-field microscopy is positive for spirochetes. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Penicillin G
Explanation: A vulvar ulcer with spirochetes (Treponema pallidum) indicates primary syphilis, treated with penicillin G (2.4 million units IM for early syphilis). Ceftriaxone, azithromycin, and metronidazole are ineffective against syphilis.
